title: Local irradiation of patient-derived tumors in immunodeficient mice
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Harvesting of patient-derived cell lines for injection
Timing: 1 h
      This step describes the harvesting, counting, and resuspension of
      patient-derived cultures prior to subcutaneous injection in the hind limb
      of NSG mice. These steps are done outside the animal facility. It
      generally takes 3–5 days since last passage until 081R or SiHa cultures
      reach 80% confluence. Regarding patient-derived cell lines, it is advised
      to take a low (<10) passage number to ensure highest possible
      similarity to the patient tissue. Group sizes should be determined by
      power calculations prior to starting the experiment.
    
      With SiHa cells, 1 × 106 cells were injected per mouse in a
      volume of 50 μL. In this step we take 081R cells as an example, injecting
      1 × 105 cells per mouse in a total volume of 50 μL.
    
        Calculate the volume and cells needed for the number of available mice,
        taking the total number of mice × 50 μL + minimal 300 μL for loss in
        syringe needle and spill.
      
Note: Example with 24 mice: 24 × 50 μL +
      300 μL = 1500 μL total.
    
        Calculate the amount of Matrigel needed (50% of total volume). Example;
        1500/2 = 750 μL.
      
Alternatives: Basement Membrane
      Extract (BME) can be used instead of Matrigel.
    
Thaw Matrigel on ice, allowing it to become liquid.
        Harvest patient-derived cells.
        
Remove medium from cells.
            Wash flask with 2 mL (T25) or 5 mL (T75) PBS.
            
                For cell lines that are hard to detach add 5 mM EDTA in PBS for
                2 min at 37°C and remove.
              
Add 1 mL (T25) or 3 mL (T75) 1× trypsin for 3–10 min at 37°C.
            Carefully resuspend the cells with long reach filter tip.
            
                Check under microscope to make sure a single-cell suspension is
                obtained.

Critical: CSC medium contains no serum
      to inactivate trypsin, and if using CSC medium, spin down cells at
      300 × g for 3 min, remove all medium and resuspend in 1–3 mL CSC
      medium.
    
Count the number of cells per mL, e.g., in a hemocytometer.
        Take 1 × 105 cells in a total of 50 μL solution for
        injection.
        
            Volume cell suspension = Total volume needed / (cells per mL /
            1 × 105 cells).
          
Example with 24 mice: 24 × 50 μL + 300 μL = 1,500 μL total.
Volume of cell suspension = 1,500 μL / 2 (50% Matrigel) = 750 μL.
      750 / (1.16 × 106 counted cells / 1 × 105) = 64.7 μL
      of cell suspension in 685.4 μL medium.
    
        Resuspend 50% of cell suspension with 50% Matrigel on ice in a 5 mL
        round-bottom polystyrene tube.
        
            After counting, make sure to freeze down a subset of cells. Document
            vials including passage number, so future mice experiments can be
            done with similar passage cell lines.
          
Transport cell-Matrigel suspension on ice to the animal facility.
Critical: Keep cells in Matrigel on
      ice to avoid solidification. To avoid cell aggregation and clumps,
      resuspend or flick the cell suspension tube right before mixing with
      Matrigel. Resuspension of the cells in Matrigel solution is essential as
      cells resuspended only in medium may fail to graft.
    
Hind limb subcutaneous injection in mice
Timing: 2 min per mouse
    
      This step describes the subcutaneous injection of patient-derived cells
      into the hind limb of mice. This procedure can be performed on one to six
      mice in a row, depending on personal skills, assistance and equipment
      available.
    
Work inside a biosafety cabinet (BSC).
        Randomize mice between different treatment groups.
        
            Distribute mice of one litter across different treatment groups and

ensure a similar number of males and females per treatment group.
          
Note: Group allocations may be corrected
      for randomization at the start of treatment (step 28).
    
Anesthetize mice with 2% Isoflurane in 100% oxygen for 5 min.
        Mark animals for identification e.g., using earmarks or color marking
        using a permanent marker.
      
        Carefully remove the hair on the right hind limb of all the mice by
        shaving (Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc2]).
      
Alternatives: Depilatory cream can
      be used.
    
Disinfect the skin with Virkon.
Resuspend pre-made cell suspension from previous steps 1–8.
        Immediately fill the 1 mL syringe to ensure a homogeneous suspension and
        attach 25G needle.
      
        Inject 50 μL cell suspension into the subcutis in the right hind limb.
        
            Inject below the kneecap, just under the skin to ensure subcutaneous
            and avoid intramuscular or intracutaneous tumor growth.

Measuring size of tumors
Timing: 3 min per mouse
    
      This step describes measuring and calculating the volume of a tumor on the
      hind limb of immunodeficient mice. Prior to measuring the tumor sizes,
      body weights should be measured on a scale.
    
Work inside a BSC.
Disinfect the digital caliper.
Note: Check if caliper is zeroed
      correctly: 0.00 should be indicated when the jaws are closed.
    
        Fixate a mouse in your left hand in such a way that the mouse right hind
        limb is freely accessible.
      
        Measure the length, width, and depth of the right (grafted) hind limb
        (Methods video S2[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc3]).
      
        When measuring for the first time, also measure the left non-tumor
        injected hind limb of each mouse.
      
Note: As the tumor volume on the hind limb
      may be hard to assess, the other hind limb is used as internal control per

mouse. In our experiments, most tumors grow subcutaneously as a distinct
      nodule, though some tumors may grow flat and into the underlying muscle
      making them difficult to measure. In most cases, the subtraction method to
      determine tumor graft is required, so we advise to apply this method for
      all mice.
    
        Calculate the average limb length for all female and the same for
        all male mice.
      
Note: As the length of the limb does not
      alter during tumor growth, this is a fixed number from this point.
    
        Calculate the volume of the tumor by measuring the tumor injected hind
        limb using the formula: (length × width × depth)/2).
        Example: (18 (average length) × 8.77 × 8.33)/2 = 657 mm3.
Alternatives: Multiple measuring
      approaches can be used to measure tumor size. Another option is the
      formula π/6∗(length × width × depth).
    
        Subtract the volume of the non-tumor injected control limb. In our case
        this was on average 107 mm3; 657–107 = 550 mm3.
      
Repeat measurements for all mice.
Document tumor measurements of each mouse over time.
        Your browser does not support HTML5 video.
      
          Methods video S2. Measuring subcutaneous tumors in hind limb, related
          to step 21
        
Localized irradiation of tumors on hind limb
Timing: 20 min per radiation fraction
    
      This step describes a radiation setup to locally radiate on the
      tumor-injected hind limb, while shielding the rest of the mouse. This
      provides a method to safely treat a broad range of tumor xenografts in
      immunodeficient mice that are unable to tolerate (scattering of) whole
      body radiation. Mice radiation-shielding setup drawings for replication
      are shown in
      Figure S1[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2461-Mmc1.pdf]
      and 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]D technical files are available on Mendeley Data:
      https://doi.org/10.17632/vfjjtwstw9.1[href=https://doi.org/10.17632/vfjjtwstw9.1].
    
        Begin treatment of mice when tumors reach approximately
        50–100 mm2.
      
Note: With 081R or SiHa cells, this was

the case after two to three weeks after injection. It is advised to start
      treatment on a Monday, so 5 times daily radiation can be applied.
    
        Assess whether randomization should be adjusted based on the size of the
        tumors, to ensure a similar mean tumor volume in each group at the start
        of treatment.
      
Select the mice to receive irradiation.
Note: In the described setup there is room
      for 4 mice at one time.
    
        Prepare 3 surgical tape sections of approximately 2–3 cm in length per
        mouse.
      
        Work inside a BSC. Anesthetize mice with 2% Isoflurane in 100% oxygen
        for 5 min.
      
        Assemble the main part of the transparent mouse restrainer; (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A, 1). Insert the front part in the main part mouse restrainer.
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2461-Fig2.jpg
              Figure 2. Restraining and local irradiation of hind limb of mice
            
              (A) Assembly of mouse restrainer and positioning of the mouse.
              Numbers are explained in the main text.
            
              (B) Assembly of shielding material. Numbers explained in the text.
            
        Position one mouse into the restrainer with the head positioned to the
        front (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A, 2).
        
            Slide the roof onto the restrainer (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A,
            3).
          
            Slide the bottom into the restrainer (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A,
            4), making sure the mouse’s tail is not stuck and the right hind
            limb is completely outside of the restrainer (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A, 5).
          
            Pull the right hind limb gently outward and forward (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A, 6).
          
            Place surgical tape behind the limb to secure its position (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A, 7).
          
            Affix tail to the restrainer roof using surgical tape to secure the
            position of the mouse (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A, 8).
          
        Position the mice in the radiation setup (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).
        
            Place the restrainer containing one mouse and place it on the bottom
            lead plate with the right limb facing the center of the setup (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B, 2).

While gently pulling the hind limb outward, secure the limb to the
            center area with surgical tape on the ankle/paw.
          
            Place the upper protective lead shielding on top of the restrainer
            (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B, 3).
          
            Repeat these steps for all 4 mice (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B,
            4).
          
            Place protective lead on top of the feet (ankle and toes) of the
            mice (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B, 4).
          
            Place the entire setup inside a transport box (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B, 5).
          
Note: Make sure the mice have access to
      oxygen during all procedures.
    
        Take the mouse containing transport box outside of the BSC and bring it
        to the radiation source. We use the radiation source XStrahl RS320,
        using a 0.5 Cu filter.
      
        Place the radiation setup with the mice on to the setup in the radiation
        source (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B, 6).
      
        Adjust the X-ray/radiation so that the beam irradiates the non-shielded
        center area of 110 mm × 110 mm.
      
Irradiate with a dose of 2 Gy at 220 kVp, 13 mA applied.
Repeat steps 30–39 daily.
Note: In our experiments, mice receive 10
      fractions in two weeks to reach a total fractionated dose of 20 Gy. The
      required dose and fractionation may differ for other cancer types, models,
      and primary outcomes, and will need optimization.
    
        Document tumor growth of each mouse three times a week during treatment
        and after treatment until tumors reach maximum tumor size.
      
Harvesting subcutaneous tumors from hind limb
Timing: 30 min per mouse
    
      Depending on the experimental setup, repeat “Measuring size of tumors”
      until a defined timepoint, tumors reach maximum tumor growth or mice reach
      a humane endpoint.
    
      This step describes how to harvest a subcutaneous tumor from the hind limb
      and process it for histology analysis, snap freezing tissue for
      transcriptomic analysis and vital freezing tissue for regrafting
      experiments.

Bring to animal facility: Bucket with ice, 4% PFA in container, labels,
        tissue cassette, microcentrifuge tubes, cryovial tubes, scissors,
        tweezer, scalpels, petri dishes.
      
        When tumors exceed maximum tumor growth as measured in previous steps or
        when reaching a humane endpoint, anesthetize mice with 2% isoflurane in
        100% oxygen for 5 min and sacrifice mice according to local legislation
        and ethical guidelines (in our case cervical dislocation).
      
Note: We use a maximum tumor growth of
      500 mm3, as we observed a necrotic core can occur in larger
      tumors. It is not advised to let tumors exceed 1,000 mm3, as
      tumors on the hind limb can cause more discomfort than on the flank (Figures 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A and 3B).

(C) Dissected hind limb and harvested tumor.

        Disinfect the right hind limb area with Virkon thoroughly. This
        functions to keep the viable frozen specimen sterile and also prevents
        loose hairs from contaminating the samples.
      
        Label tissue cassette, screwcap microcentrifuge tube, and viable
        freezing vial.
      
        Carefully harvest the tumor from the hind leg of the mice (Methods video S3[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc4], Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C) and place the tumor on a 100 mm2
        petri dish.
      
        Cut the tumor with a scalpel in to three sections. Cut from edge to
        center, so edge and center are equally represented in each stored tissue
        section (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]D).
      
        Divide the tumor sections (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]E).
        
Place one tissue section inside a labeled tissue cassette.

Place one tissue section into a 0.5 mL screw cap microcentrifuge
            tube and put on ice.
          
            Place one tissue section into a viable freezing vial and put on ice.
          
Take samples from mice facility to Biosafety level 1 laboratory.

Processing and characterization of xenograft tissue
Timing: 1 week
      This section describes processing of the harvested xenograft tissue in the
      previous steps. This includes long term storage for transcriptomic
      analyses or other characterization, vital freezing and preparation for
      histological and immunohistochemical assessment.
    
        Snap freeze tissue.
        
Add liquid nitrogen in a Dewar carrying flask.
            Take samples from ice and submerge screw cap vials in liquid
            nitrogen.
            
Note: Snap freezing increases RNA
              preservation for e.g., transcriptomic analyses.
            
Store labeled vials at −80°C until further analyses.
        Vital freeze tissue.
        
            Get freezing container (“Mr. Frosty”) out of −80°C freezer in
            advance.
          
            Take the cryovial from ice, clean it with 70% EtOH and place into a
            BSC.
          
Add 0.5 mL freezing medium to cryovial containing the tissue.
            Place the vials in a freezing container and freeze the tissue
            overnight (16 h).
          
Place vials following day in the liquid nitrogen freezer.
            Years after long term storage, tissue can be regrafted in mice, for
            instance to assess effects of applied treatments on long-term
            clonogenicity.8[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]
        Process tissue for histology assessment.
        
            Submerge the cassette in 4% buffered PFA, in a closed container.
          
            Next day remove the 4% PFA and replace by 70% ethanol for 1–7 days.
          
            Process tissue and stain for hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)
            according to Aziz et al.9[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9]
        Assess histology of the tissue by H&E staining and determine the
        boundaries of the tumor tissue (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A).
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2461-Fig4.jpg

(A) Histopathology by H&E of control and radiation treated
              tumor harvested as shown in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]. Scale
              bar is 500 μm. Pink edges: myocyte tissue. Purple: tumor tissue.
            
              (B) Tumor sections as shown in Figure panel A, processed for
              γ-H2AX immunohistochemistry, using DAB (brown) to visualize target
              protein. Scale bar 200 μm.
            
        Immunohistochemically stain tissue for γ-H2AX (phosphorylated H2A
        histone family member X, a marker indicative of DNA damage) with a
        subtle (30 s) Hematoxylin background according to Nagelkerke et al.10[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10]
        Specifically in the tumor tissue established with H&E staining,
        validate radiation efficacy by induction of γ-H2AX immunohistochemistry
        (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B).
